content.raw: The `PagingPath` is `static`, so it's shared across instances of the `HeightMap` class.  But the contents of that directory are removed in the [constructor](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/687/terrain-paging-support-for-rendering/diff#Lgazebo/rendering/Heightmap.ccT56) and [destructor](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/687/terrain-paging-support-for-rendering/diff#Lgazebo/rendering/Heightmap.ccT76), which will be called for each `HeightMap` instance.  Is that safe to do?  Can there be more than one `HeightMap` instance?
content.html: The PagingPath is static, so it's shared across instances of the HeightMap class. But the contents of that directory are removed in the constructor and destructor, which will be called for each HeightMap instance. Is that safe to do? Can there be more than one HeightMap instance?

content.raw:
`PagingPath` shouldn't be static. There currently can only be one `HeightMap` but that limitation will go away in the future.

Rename `PagingPath` to `pagingPath`
content.html:
PagingPath shouldn't be static. There currently can only be one HeightMap but that limitation will go away in the future.

Rename PagingPath to pagingPath

content.raw:
Fixed in 9462613.

I have created a common directory under the temporal directory. Then, every gazebo instance create a unique directory under the common directory. For now, I remove the common directory in the Heightmap constructor for avoiding to accumulate a lot of old data (and assuming there's only one gazebo instance).
content.html:
Fixed in 9462613.

I have created a common directory under the temporal directory. Then, every gazebo instance create a unique directory under the common directory. For now, I remove the common directory in the Heightmap constructor for avoiding to accumulate a lot of old data (and assuming there's only one gazebo instance).

content.raw:
Suggest using `boost::filesystem::temp_directory_path()` to get the temporary directory, instead of assuming that `/tmp` will work (one of these days, we will run on Windows...).

Also, what happens if multiple instance of gazebo are running simultaneously?  Should each one use a unique path to store terrain pages (e.g., via `boost::filesystem::unique_path()`)?
content.html:
Suggest using boost::filesystem::temp_directory_path() to get the temporary directory, instead of assuming that /tmp will work (one of these days, we will run on Windows...).

Also, what happens if multiple instance of gazebo are running simultaneously? Should each one use a unique path to store terrain pages (e.g., via boost::filesystem::unique_path())?

content.raw:
Thanks for the suggestion Brian. The only problem that I see is that right now I remove all the terrain page files in the Heightmap constructor. This is a guarantee for not using any previous terrain page files. If there are multiple gazebo instances I cannot do this because a directory might be used by a current instance.

By using unique directory names I could let the directory as it is, and assume that it will be removed by the OS later. Although this solution is not really clean...

Any other idea?
content.html:
Thanks for the suggestion Brian. The only problem that I see is that right now I remove all the terrain page files in the Heightmap constructor. This is a guarantee for not using any previous terrain page files. If there are multiple gazebo instances I cannot do this because a directory might be used by a current instance.

By using unique directory names I could let the directory as it is, and assume that it will be removed by the OS later. Although this solution is not really clean...

Any other idea?

content.raw:
This should go toward the end of the class:

```
#!c++


class <name>
{
  public functions
  protected functions
  private functions

  public variables
  protected variables
  private variables.
}

```
The name of the variables should also start with a lower case letter.
content.html:
This should go toward the end of the class:

class <name>
{
  public functions
  protected functions
  private functions

  public variables
  protected variables
  private variables.
}

The name of the variables should also start with a lower case letter.

content.raw: Probably out of scope for this pull request, but I'm curious: why are we limited to splitting into 4 or 16 pieces?  Naively, it seems like the number of pieces should be determined as a function of the terrain size and the desired size of each piece.
content.html: Probably out of scope for this pull request, but I'm curious: why are we limited to splitting into 4 or 16 pieces? Naively, it seems like the number of pieces should be determined as a function of the terrain size and the desired size of each piece.

content.raw:
Ogre imposes some constraints for the terrain size:

  * Terrains must be square
  * The number of vertices along the edge of the terrain should be 2^n+1

When I split the terrain I should keep these constrains for each piece. In addition the pieces must have the same size. That essentially forces us to use a n^2 number of pieces, where n must satisfy the previous conditions. 4 and 16 worked fine. The next value is 64, but for some reason that I do not understand did not work. I know it is related with another internal tile division that Ogre performs. [MinBatchSize](http://www.ogre3d.org/docs/api/html/structOgre_1_1Terrain_1_1ImportData.html#a60b1682048188053cc885097eb2383c6) and [MaxBatchSize](http://www.ogre3d.org/docs/api/html/structOgre_1_1Terrain_1_1ImportData.html#acebf6cfa7dcb63b4725ed1dc2e63a9f2) has to be adjusted properly but all my tests did not work.
content.html:
Ogre imposes some constraints for the terrain size:

  • Terrains must be square
  • The number of vertices along the edge of the terrain should be 2^n+1

When I split the terrain I should keep these constrains for each piece. In addition the pieces must have the same size. That essentially forces us to use a n^2 number of pieces, where n must satisfy the previous conditions. 4 and 16 worked fine. The next value is 64, but for some reason that I do not understand did not work. I know it is related with another internal tile division that Ogre performs. MinBatchSize and MaxBatchSize has to be adjusted properly but all my tests did not work.

content.raw:
Loading `heightmap.world` takes much longer when paging is enabled.  On my laptop (admittedly, a MacBook Air, with poor GPU support):

* Without paging:

        Heightmap::Load start: 1378330462.765149
        Heightmap::Load end: 1378330465.431348

* With paging:

        Heightmap::Load start: 1378330414.999794
        Heightmap::Load end: 1378330440.449800

I.e., ~2.5s without paging vs. ~25.5s with paging.  I'll poke around to see where the time goes.
content.html:
Loading heightmap.world takes much longer when paging is enabled. On my laptop (admittedly, a MacBook Air, with poor GPU support):

  • Without paging:

    Heightmap::Load start: 1378330462.765149
Heightmap::Load end: 1378330465.431348

  • With paging:

    Heightmap::Load start: 1378330414.999794
Heightmap::Load end: 1378330440.449800

I.e., ~2.5s without paging vs. ~25.5s with paging. I'll poke around to see where the time goes.

content.raw: That's probably because Ogre generates a set of files with terrain information in order to use the paging. Although I have to admit that's a lot of time!
content.html: That's probably because Ogre generates a set of files with terrain information in order to use the paging. Although I have to admit that's a lot of time!

content.raw: and probably also takes time to save terrains to file in this [line](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/687/terrain-paging-support-for-rendering/diff#Lgazebo/rendering/Heightmap.ccT317)
content.html: and probably also takes time to save terrains to file in this line

content.raw: Yeah, it seems like most of the time is in Ogre's `saveAllTerrains()` call.  Maybe there's a way to cache and reuse the generated subterrains from previous runs?  That would require appropriate checksumming to make sure that the right data is being used.  Probably should be an optimization that we add later.
content.html: Yeah, it seems like most of the time is in Ogre's saveAllTerrains() call. Maybe there's a way to cache and reuse the generated subterrains from previous runs? That would require appropriate checksumming to make sure that the right data is being used. Probably should be an optimization that we add later.

content.raw: I'll create a separate pull request for this. I'll compute a SHA1 hash of the original image, and create a file with the hash inside for every world. Thanks for the suggestion Brian.
content.html: I'll create a separate pull request for this. I'll compute a SHA1 hash of the original image, and create a file with the hash inside for every world. Thanks for the suggestion Brian.

content.raw:
Thanks for all the comments and suggestions. Updated with all the suggestions so far. 

The only outstanding issue is how to deal with paging files if multiple gazebo instances are running. For now, I am assuming that there's only one instance. The only solution I have at the moment is to comment the line that removes the directory that contains the paging files, and assume that in the future this files will be removed because they are under a temporal directory (not really clean).
content.html:
Thanks for all the comments and suggestions. Updated with all the suggestions so far.

The only outstanding issue is how to deal with paging files if multiple gazebo instances are running. For now, I am assuming that there's only one instance. The only solution I have at the moment is to comment the line that removes the directory that contains the paging files, and assume that in the future this files will be removed because they are under a temporal directory (not really clean).

content.raw: So, as suggested, I do not erase any paging files during the gazebo startup. That allows multiple gazebo instances running with paging.
content.html: So, as suggested, I do not erase any paging files during the gazebo startup. That allows multiple gazebo instances running with paging.

content.html: Is this line required?

content.html: Not anymore because now we do not remove terrain page files from previous runs. Fixed in ed36a0d

content.raw: Updated with a modification in RenderEngine.cc to call the Scene's destructor during gazebo shutdown.
content.html: Updated with a modification in RenderEngine.cc to call the Scene's destructor during gazebo shutdown.

content.raw:
This is not ideal. Explicitly calling a destructor can lead to undefined behavior (such as double free). The scene pointer in this case is a boost shared pointer, so the destructor should get called automatically when all instances are released (see the line `this->scenes.clear()` below). 

I also noticed that `Scene::Clear` destroys the heightmap. This line is probably not needed.
content.html:
This is not ideal. Explicitly calling a destructor can lead to undefined behavior (such as double free). The scene pointer in this case is a boost shared pointer, so the destructor should get called automatically when all instances are released (see the line this->scenes.clear() below).

I also noticed that Scene::Clear destroys the heightmap. This line is probably not needed.

content.raw:
I was not really happy with the explicit destructor call but I noticed that the scene destructor was not called. I don't need it for the heighmap but I thought it was convenient that the destructor was executed in any case.

Let me take a look at this
content.html:
I was not really happy with the explicit destructor call but I noticed that the scene destructor was not called. I don't need it for the heighmap but I thought it was convenient that the destructor was executed in any case.

Let me take a look at this

content.raw:
Updated with a better way of calling the scene's destructor.

I have found what it looks a little problem stopping gazebo. Some times a got this message after CTRL-C:


```
#!c++

pure virtual method called
terminate called without an active exception
```

It seems that some thread deletes a resource on shutdown but other thread still tries to access the same resource. It happens with different branches and worlds. I'll file a ticket.
content.html:
Updated with a better way of calling the scene's destructor.

I have found what it looks a little problem stopping gazebo. Some times a got this message after CTRL-C:

pure virtual method called
terminate called without an active exception

It seems that some thread deletes a resource on shutdown but other thread still tries to access the same resource. It happens with different branches and worlds. I'll file a ticket.
